Agency: Treasury Department Financial Crimes Enforcement Network

Description: AmSouth Bank and AmSouth Asset Management agreed to pay $11.4 million to settle allegations that they defrauded AmSouth mutual funds by secretly using a portion of administrative fees paid by fund shareholders for marketing and other unrelated expenses that should have been paid by AmSouth itself.

Regions Bank agreed to pay $52.4 million to the United States to resolve allegations that it violated the False Claims Act by knowingly originating and underwriting mortgage loans insured by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's Federal Housing Administration that did not meet applicable requirements.

The Federal Reserve Board announced that Regions Bank, Birmingham, Alabama, would pay a $46 million penalty for misconduct related to the process followed by the bank in the first quarter of 2009 for identifying and reporting non-accrual loans.

The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau took action against Regions Bank for charging overdraft fees to consumers who had not opted-in for overdraft coverage. The bank also charged overdraft and non-sufficient funds fees on its deposit advance product despite claims that it would not. Regions has already refunded hundreds of thousands of consumers approximately $49 million in fees, and the consent order required the bank to fully refund all remaining consumers. The Bureau also fined the company $7.5 million for its illegal actions.

The SEC announced that othe District Court for the Southern District of Florida entered a Final Judgment against Regions Bank for its role in connection with a Florida-based offering fraud by unregistered broker-dealers U.S. Pension Trust Corp. and U.S. College Trust Corp. The final judgment required Regions Bank to pay disgorgement of $1.00 and a civil penalty in the amount of $1,000,000 into a Fair Fund for the benefit of investors injured in USPT's faud. Regions Bank consented to the entry of the final judgment without admitting or denying any allegations of the complaint (except as to jurisdiction), waived findings of fact and conclusions of law, and waived any right to appeal from this final judgment.
Regions Bank agreed to pay $1 million to settle allegations relating to its role in an offering fraud that victimized thousands of investors predominantly in Latin America.

Notes: Description field shows type of discrimination that EEOC had alleged.

Private Litigation Case Title: Wilson et al v. Regions Financial Corporation

Description: The settlement amount listed here refers only to the ERISA portion of a larger multidistrict case.
Private Litigation Case Title: Hamby v. Morgan Asset Management, Inc. et al

Description: Regions Bank agreed to pay the Alabama Department of Banking $5 million for misconduct related to the process followed by the bank in the first quarter of 2009 for identifying and reporting non-accrual loans. This was part of a case in which the bank separately paid $46 million to the Federal Reserve; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/al-regions-bank
AmSouth agreed to pay a total of $225,000 to regulators in Alabama and Mississippi to resolve a case involving deceptive practices by one of its broker-dealers.

Info Source: Contained in data received from the agency on January 25, 2021 in response to an open records request. The data was a spreadsheet compilation of information in the search engine at http://tdec.tn.gov:8080/pls/enf_reports/f?p=9001:710::::::

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 1, 2022 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division atâ¬Ã¡https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.
